For export packages, the plugin removes the qualifier from the version when it is *-SNAPSHOT and thus we have only
${versionNumber.major}.${versionNumber.minor}.${versionNumber.micro} which is not correct for snapshots versions.
Better option here will be to add BUILD-timestamp thus we will be able to distinguish between the different snapshot versions.

There is an BND instruction that tells BND what to do when an "-SNAPSHOT" qualifier is encountered in the bundle version: https://bnd.bndtools.org/instructions/snapshot.html
One possibility would be to use:
-snapshot: BUILD-${tstamp}
Which would change:
Bundle-Version: 3.4.1-SNAPSHOT
to
Bundle-Version: 3.4.1.202011251350
When the version does NOT end with -SNAPSHOT the version is kept so:
Bundle-Version: 3.4.1
would be kept as
Bundle-Version: 3.4.1

Yes but then when you have two bundles with 3.4.1.202011251350 and 3.4.1 and import package [3.4, 3.5) the first will be preferred correct? While we want the bundles produced by the release to be preferred in comparison to the SNAPSHOT builds.
So the snapshots will be 3.4.1.BUILD-202011251350 while the release will be 3.4.1.RELEASE so that when importing like this [3.4, 3.5), a released version to be preferred.
Is that correct?

🤕👿  now I'm not changing the Bundle-Version for -SNAPSHOT but instead using the bnd instruction "-snapshot" : 'BUILD-${tstamp}' and what I get is this:

Created-By: 14.0.2 (AdoptOpenJDK)
Export-Package: reactor.adapter;uses:="org.reactivestreams,reactor.cor
 e.publisher";version="3.4.1.SNAPSHOT"
oh what a joy!

Bundle-Version: 3.4.1.BUILD-202011251646

Assuming OSGi uses the same version order for packages it would rank release packages before snapshot packages which would be good. If there are multiple bundles which provide the same package with the same version maybe the bundle version is then used for ordering that would mean the package version qualifier wouldn't be strictly required but I'm not sure.

According to the spec:
https://docs.osgi.org/specification/osgi.core/7.0.0/service.resolver.html#i3344409
For resolving an OSGi framework the specifications outlines a number of heuristics that guide the order of wiring bundles and packages:

A resource that is already resolved, that is, it is already wired
The highest version
The lowest bundle id

Therefore I would assume that the same version order used for Bundle-Version is also used for the package version 🙂

Let's assume that you have two bundles with the following versions Bundle-Version: 3.4.1.BUILD-1 and the second Bundle-Version: 3.4.1.BUILD-2. The first one has an issue and the second one no. You want to test both of them in order to find the issue.
Both bundles are installed and your bundle wants to test both of them. You can do it very easy when specifying the concrete export-package version when you importing the package.
You do not need to install/uninstall bundles, you do not need to require a bundle.
Is that a valid scenario or if you think that you are just fine with the current solution we can do it like this.
I just don't think that this is valid
Bundle-Version: 3.4.1.BUILD-202011251646
Export-Package: xyz;version=3.4.1

Typically export packages follow the bundle version.
https://github.com/eclipse/gemini.web.gemini-web-container/blob/39fd5cc49d266178fb1adcda89feb7413fca98e2/org.eclipse.gemini.web.core/template.mf#L15

@violetagg you are right that might be a valid use-case and the changes required are not that big. In many OSGi specific projects packages are versioned completely separately than the bundle version but for projects like this one it might be a good idea to include the qualifier for the exported packages.

@simonbasle  I think the issue with the -snapshot version was here. BND is processing -snaptshot the Bundle-Version attribute AFTER it's processing the exports.
The reason for that is that you wouldn't want to have export-package versions like 3.4.1.BUILD-202011261127 but you always want to have export-package versions like 3.4.1
Therefore at the point of the export-package attribute OSGi sees following version:
3.4.1-SNAPSHOT
which OSGi can't parse as a valid OSGi version because OSGi would require a qualifier with a dot (.):
3.4.1.SNAPSHOT
When the Bundle-Version is not a valid OSGi version the qualifier is not removed for package exports as BND does for valid OSGi versions. So for Export-Package BND would convert the Bundle-Version "3.4.1.SNAPSHOT" into "3.4.1" for package exports (valid OSGi version, stripping qualifier) but when it's not a valid OSGi version as with "3.4.1-SNAPSHOT" the version is kept as it is so it results in "3.4.1-SNAPTSHOT" package versions.
I would say that this is really inconvenient and I will create a BND issue for that.
As a result of that to get proper Export-Package versions we would need to define a custom osgiVersion anyways because we would need to convert the maven version 3.4.1-SNAPSHOT into 3.4.1.SNAPSHOT here therefore using the bnd instruction -snapshot is not really worth it because we have to do the version conversion anyway.

I have seen that "-noimport:=true" is used in the reactor-test module we could use that here too which would make the manifest a little bit cleaner because the exported packages are then not listed in the import-package attribute and there is not really any downside to it (that I know of).
The specification says following (3.6.5):

An export definition does not imply an automatic import definition. A bundle that exports a package and does not import that package will get that package via its bundle class path. Such an exported only package can be used by other bundles, but the exporting bundle does not accept a substitution for this package from another bundle.

I just think that it should be consistent between all reactor modules. So if you use -noimport for one module it should be used for the others too if not than it should be removed for the reactor-test module (?)

please open a separate issue/pr if you find that causes actual problems, I don't want to change anything that isn't strictly necessary and directly related to the new version scheme in this PR so that the commit serves as a reference for other projects (addons notably)
The idea with -noimport:=true is very good as if we have an import package the functionality will be taken from the import and not from the class path.
